title: Perry hits Clinton for dissing Texas on voter IDs
content:
Rick Perry is pressing his attack on Hillary Clinton on voting rights , accusing her of calling out Texas voters for their support of voter ID laws .
Asked about the Democratic front-runner ’ s speech last week , in which she railed against voter ID laws like those in Texas , Perry said Clinton was alienating voters .
“ This is a state issue , ” said the former Republican governor of Texas , who often invokes states ’ rights and the 10th Amendment . “ This is an issue that the people of the state of Texas overwhelmingly support . … I don ’ t know who she ’ s playing to , but she ’ s not playing to the people of the state of Texas . ”
In 2011 , Texas passed a strict voter identification law required for voters at the polls , which was upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court .
In an interview from Boone , Iowa , aired Sunday on CNN ’ s “ State of the Union , ” Perry said Clinton was “ way outside the norm of ridiculous ” in her call for easier voter ID laws , asserting Texas already makes it easy for residents to vote .
In a speech in Texas on Thursday , Clinton for the first time called out Perry — along with three other GOP presidential hopefuls — Govs . Scott Walker of Wisconsin , Chris Christie of New Jersey and former Florida Gov . Jeb Bush — for their support for voter ID laws and opposition to early voting . The next day , Perry on Fox News accused Clinton of “ taking on ” Texas voters for supporting the voter ID law .
Clinton ’ s rapid-response team , Correct the Record , responded later Sunday to Perry ’ s criticisms on “ State of the Union . ”
“ Republicans like Rick Perry are trying to deny citizens this fundamental right [ to vote ] , under the fictional specter of voter fraud , ” communications director Adrienne Watson wrote in an email to ███ . “ Perry needs to answer for his actions to disenfranchise the voters of Texas — such as the law he signed that was intentionally written to discriminate against minority voters . ”
In his CNN interview , Perry also defended the populist tone of his announcement speech on Thursday , taking another shot at Wall Street banks .
“ I don ’ t think it ’ s right for Wall Street to be able to walk away from bad mistakes that the people on Main Street have to pay for , ” he said about the so-called too big to fail banks . “ If that ’ s populism , then I ’ m proud to be a populist on that issue . ”
Asked later on CBS ’ “ Face the Nation ” about what he ’ d do to prevent reckless Wall Street behavior , Perry said , “ regulate them , ” though he added that he believed the Dodd-Frank regulatory reforms signed by President Barack Obama went too far and were harming community banks .
The former governor launched his second straight presidential campaign on Thursday with an upbeat , muscular speech in an airplane hangar outside Addison , Texas . He did the CNN interview Saturday at Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst ’ s “ Roast and Ride ” event , where Perry rode a motorcycle and addressed the crowd in blue jeans and a baseball cap .
On Thursday , influential conservative activist Sam Clovis signed on to head Perry ’ s Iowa operation — a big coup for the former governor , who beat out Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and other conservative GOP hopefuls for his services .

Perry hits Clinton for dissing Texas on voter IDs

Rick Perry is pressing his attack on Hillary Clinton on voting rights, accusing her of calling out Texas voters for their support of voter ID laws.

Asked about the Democratic front-runner’s speech last week, in which she railed against voter ID laws like those in Texas, Perry said Clinton was alienating voters.

“This is a state issue,” said the former Republican governor of Texas, who often invokes states’ rights and the 10th Amendment. “This is an issue that the people of the state of Texas overwhelmingly support. … I don’t know who she’s playing to, but she’s not playing to the people of the state of Texas.”

In 2011, Texas passed a strict voter identification law required for voters at the polls, which was upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court.

In an interview from Boone, Iowa, aired Sunday on CNN’s “State of the Union,” Perry said Clinton was “way outside the norm of ridiculous” in her call for easier voter ID laws, asserting Texas already makes it easy for residents to vote.

In a speech in Texas on Thursday, Clinton for the first time called out Perry — along with three other GOP presidential hopefuls — Govs. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, Chris Christie of New Jersey and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush — for their support for voter ID laws and opposition to early voting. The next day, Perry on Fox News accused Clinton of “taking on” Texas voters for supporting the voter ID law.

Clinton’s rapid-response team, Correct the Record, responded later Sunday to Perry’s criticisms on “State of the Union.”

“Republicans like Rick Perry are trying to deny citizens this fundamental right [to vote], under the fictional specter of voter fraud,” communications director Adrienne Watson wrote in an email to POLITICO. “Perry needs to answer for his actions to disenfranchise the voters of Texas — such as the law he signed that was intentionally written to discriminate against minority voters.”

In his CNN interview, Perry also defended the populist tone of his announcement speech on Thursday, taking another shot at Wall Street banks.

“I don’t think it’s right for Wall Street to be able to walk away from bad mistakes that the people on Main Street have to pay for,” he said about the so-called too big to fail banks. “If that’s populism, then I’m proud to be a populist on that issue.”

Asked later on CBS’ “Face the Nation” about what he’d do to prevent reckless Wall Street behavior, Perry said, “regulate them,” though he added that he believed the Dodd-Frank regulatory reforms signed by President Barack Obama went too far and were harming community banks.

The former governor launched his second straight presidential campaign on Thursday with an upbeat, muscular speech in an airplane hangar outside Addison, Texas. He did the CNN interview Saturday at Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst’s “Roast and Ride” event, where Perry rode a motorcycle and addressed the crowd in blue jeans and a baseball cap.

On Thursday, influential conservative activist Sam Clovis signed on to head Perry’s Iowa operation — a big coup for the former governor, who beat out Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and other conservative GOP hopefuls for his services.
